<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_tortoise_detectcycles:
```c
static int lfs_tortoise_detectcycles(
    const lfs_mdir_t *dir, struct lfs_tortoise_t *tortoise) {
    // detect cycles with Brent's algorithm
    if (lfs_pair_issync(dir->tail, tortoise->pair)) {
        LFS_WARN("Cycle detected in tail list");
        return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
    }
    if (tortoise->i == tortoise->period) {
        tortoise->pair[0] = dir->tail[0];
        tortoise->pair[1] = dir->tail[1];
        tortoise->i = 0;
        tortoise->period *= 2;
    }
    tortoise->i += 1;

    return LFS_ERR_OK;
}
```

explanation: Rule 14.3 concerns invariant controlling expressions (typically loop conditions). This function contains no loop constructs (for, while, do-while), so there are no loop controlling expressions to evaluate against the rule. Other statements in the function are assignments, an increment, warnings, and return statements — none are controlling expressions for loops. The two listed conditional statements are the only controlling expressions present; they depend on runtime values (function parameters and struct members) rather than compile-time constants, so other lines do not need investigation under Rule 14.3.
